conclusion: Consider the principles of light and shadow to determine shadow changes.
The light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows on the ground.
The objects (A, B, C, and D) are placed on the ground.
Shadows are formed by the objects and the light source; the position of the light source affects the size and shape of the shadows.
If the light source moves forward, it will cast longer shadows on the ground due to the increased distance between the light source and the objects.
Shadow A will become longer and more pronounced due to the increased distance between the lamp and the light source.
Shadow B will become longer and more pronounced due to the increased distance between the cookie and the light source.
Shadow C will become longer and more pronounced due to the increased distance between the cake and the light source.
Shadow D will become longer and more pronounced due to the increased distance between the ice cream and the light source.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will become longer and more pronounced when the light source moves forward above the objects.
